Table 1 Image, table 1 Catalyst Conditions E/Z TON or TOF Ref. metallic Cu0 MeCN, rt, 2 h, Air >99:1 TON=2535 [31] Cu3N nanocubes EtOH, 30 °C, 1 h, Ar >99:1 TON=912 [34] Cu1 O(I)/CeO2 EtOH, 90 °C, 1 h, N2 99:1 TON=198 [41] Cu1-TiC Toluene, 80 °C, 24 h, Ar >99:1 TON=612 [42] JNM-4-Ns MeCN/H2O, rt, 20 min, Ar >99:1 TOF=41,734 h-1 [43] Cu-MOFs EtOH, rt, 1 h, Ar >99:1 TOF=310 h-1 [45] PCN-222 EtOH/H2O, 80 °C, 4 h, Air >99:1 TOF=16.5 h-1 [46] Cu4 clusters MeCN/H2O, rt, 1 h, Air >99:1 TON=77,786 [48] RhRu CNT Neat, rt, 24 h, N2 >99:1 TON=2400 [54] Au1Cu14 MeCN, rt, 2 h, N2 20:1 TOF=4850 h-1 [55] Review Paper Nanometal catalysts for the hydroboration of alkynes Xianghua Zeng Writing – review & editing College of Biological, Chemical Science and Engineering, Jiaxing University, Jiaxing 314001, PR China College of Biological Chemical Science and Engineering Jiaxing University Jiaxing 314001 PR China College of Biological, Chemical Science and Engineering, Jiaxing University, Jiaxing 314001, PR China The hydroboration of alkynes using transition metal catalysts is one of the most straightforward and effective methods for synthesizing value-added vinylboronates that support various industries, including materials science, agrochemicals and pharmaceuticals. However, most existing reports focus on homogeneous catalysis and are largely limited to recover the catalysts and metal contamination into products. In recent years, the use of metal-based heterogeneous catalysts has emerged as a powerful strategy to overcome these limitations. In this mini review, we summarize the employment of nanometal catalysts in the hydroboration reactions, and the related mechanisms are also discussed. Additionally, we discuss the challenges and future perspectives for promoting nanocatalysis, highlighting the potential to drive advancements towards sustainability in hydroboration of alkynes. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Advances in the hydroboration of alkynes using nanometal as catalysts are summarized. Keywords Nanometal catalyst Green Synthesis Alkynes Hydroboration Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Developing efficient catalytic approaches produce chemical products is a key requirement for chemical sustainability [1–3]. From both economical and ecological viewpoints, the use of environmentally-benign catalysts, their recycling, or the simple separation of catalysts from reaction mixtures are very important in chemical industry [4–6]. Recently, metallic nanoparticles and nanoclusters have been used as an alternative catalysts in organic synthesis due to their high reactivity, high stability, high dispersivity and recyclability. It should be noted that the high reactivity is result from the large surface area of nanocatalysts [7]. Due to these features, nanometal catalysts have been used successfully in CC, CN, CO, C-B, C-S cross-coupling reactions [8–10]. Organoboron compounds are attractive for organic synthesis due to their high functional group tolerance, diversity, low toxicity, and ease of access and handling [11–14]. Among them, vinylboronates are regarded as key building blocks in the construction of numerous complex molecules, such as organic semiconductors, pharmaceuticals and materials science [15–17]. In addition, vinylboron reagents are often used as precursors in cross-coupling reactions, such as the Mizoroki-Heck reaction, the Suzuki-Miyaura reaction, and the ring-closing metathesis reaction [18–22]. Consequently, numerous methodologies have been developed to produce these valuable compounds. Borylation of alkynes, followed by protonation, is one of the most alluring routes to generate vinylboronates with high regioselectivity [23]. So far, significant efforts have been made for the hydroboration of alkynes with heterogeneous nanometal as catalyst due to its high efficiency and recyclability. Therefore, this mini review surveys the advancements of nanometal catalytic in the field of hydroboration of alkynes in recent years. We have discussed the reactions in a detailed way with discussion of nanometal catalytic systems including the mechanistic illustrations. 2 Result and discussion 2.1 Nano copper catalyzed hydroboration of alkynes Copper is easy availability and low cost. The Cu-based nanocatalysts have shown large reaction diversity due to the various oxidation states of copper, such as Cu0, CuI, CuII, and CuIII [24,25]. Early in 2011, Garcia and coworkers have founded the copper(II) oxide nanoparticles supported on magnesia exhibited high activity for hydroboration of alkynes with bis(pinacolato)diboron assisted by triphenylphophine (Scheme 1 ) [26]. This nanocatalysis system showed good regio- and stereoselectivity for aromatic and aliphatic, terminal as well internal alkynes and occurred with high chemoselectivity for the CC triple bond versus the CC double bond. Later, a polycrystalline CuO nanoparticles supported on carbon nanofibers (CNF) was prepared in one pot utilizing a simple solid-state grinding followed by thermal treatment under nitrogen flow in the absence of surfactant, reducing agent solvent, which could be used for hydroboration of alkynes with high regioselectivites under mild conditions (Scheme 2 ) [27]. In 2014, Li and Fu reported that the micro Cu powder promoted the hydroboration of alkynes with ligand free at room temperature [28]. Park’s group then reported superparamagnetic Copper ferrite (CuFe2O4) NPs in the hydroboration of alkynes under air atmosphere [29]. In addition, this nano CuFe2O4catalyst could be easily reusable using an external magnetic field at least four times. Based on these pioneering works, Zeng and co-workers designed a nano Cu(0)-CuFe2O4 catalyst for the hydroboration of alkynes, in which the Cu(0)@CuFe2O4 was synthesized by a solvothermal reaction (Scheme 3 ) [30]. The new nanocopper was proved to a highly efficient catalyst in the selective hydroboration of alkynes. The alkynes containing carbonyl functionality resulted in selective reduction of carbon-carbon triple bond but the C = O double bond was reserved under the reaction conditions. Key to the success of this catalytic cycle is generate copper-boryl species by reaction of Cu-CuFe2O4 with bis(pinacolato)diboron (B2Pin2) in the presence of NaOMe, along with subsequent insertion of a CC triple bond. Notably, the Cu@CuFe2O4 magnetic nanocatalyst could be reused more than six consecutive times. In 2025, Bose et al. developed an efficient zero-valent cop per-catalyzed hydroboration of alkynes with easily handled B2Pin2 as a boron source for the synthesis of vinylboronate under mild reaction conditions (Scheme 4 ) [31]. The metallic Cu0 (MCU) catalyst was synthesized from Cu(SO4)2·5H2O, benzene-1,4-dicarboxylic acid and N,N-dimethylformamide treated with at 200 °C for 8 h under solvothermal conditions. Notably, this reusable Cu° could also catalyzed carboboration of alkynes using carbon elec trophiles and B2Pin2 as chemical feedstocks with appreciable turnover number of up to 2535. In 2017, Huang et al. discovered the intrinsic ability of copper nanocubes for hydroboration of various substituted aryl alkynes [32]. As shown in Scheme 5 , the copper nanocubes exhibited good catalytic performance for hydroboration of aromatic alkynes, delivering the corresponding products in good to excellent yields with 100 % (E)-product selectivity. Notably, the copper nanocubes with average sizes of 82, 95, and 108 nm could be synthesized from cetyltrimethylammonium chloride surfactant, copper acetate, and sodium ascorbate reductant through an aqueous mixture of heating at 100 °C for 40 min. Subsequently, the author compared cubes, octahedra and rhombic dodecahedra Cu2O crystals as the catalysts for hydroboration reactions (Scheme 6 ) [33]. Interestingly, the Cu2O rhombic dodecahedra presented a higher catalytic activity. These results are consistent with the fact that the {110} faces of Cu2O are most catalytically active due to their fully exposed copper atoms in the catalytic process. In 2023, Mizugaki and coworkers reported a copper nitride nanocube (Cu3N NC) catalyst for hydroboration of alkynes at room temperature (Scheme 7 ) [34]. Owing to the co-existence of the Lewis acid and base sites on Cu3N NCs, it could activate B2Pin2 to form Cu-Bpin species with additive-free. In addition, the Cu3N NCs could be reused through simple filtration. In 2018, Sui and co-workers reported a novel catalyst of copper embedded in a silylated nanocellulose (SNC) sponge (Cu@SNC) for the hydroboration of terminal alkynes under argon atmosphere (Scheme 8 ) [35]. Notably, the sponge showed high mechanical and chemical stabilities and easily recovered 94 % of its shape in water. Xu et al. also reported encapsulation of nano copper in permeable silicone elastomers for hydroboration of terminal alkynes at room temperature (Scheme 9 ) [36]. In their effort to probe the advantages of copper-based nanoparticles in catalysis, Zheng and coworkers discovered that the Cu nanospheres on reduced graphene oxide (rGO) could efficiently syn-boronation of terminal alkynes in N2 atmosphere, leading to (E)-β-styrene boronate esters in high yields (Scheme 10 ) [37]. To explore the regioselective boronation process, a series of deuterium labeling experiments were performed. At last, they concluded that MeOH acted as a proton donor and rGO facilitated the proton transfer process. In 2023, Xie and coworkers reported a nano copper supported on the porous polyvinyl chloride (Cu@PVC) for the hydroboration of alkynes with good yields and excellent regioselectivity at room temperature (Scheme 11 ) [38]. Notably, the Cu@PVC could also be reused more than five runs. In 2025, Hu and coworkers disclosed Cu-site in HKUST-1 for efficiently promoting alkali-free hydroboration of terminal alkyne under room temperature [39]. The advantages of MOFs includes their tunable properties and high catalytic activity [40]. In recent years, single-atom catalysis has become a new frontier in heterogeneous catalysis. For example, Wang and Li reported a CeO2-supported single-atomic-site Cu catalyst for hydroboration of alkynes with no additives in 2020 (Scheme 12 ) [41]. Two types of single-atomic-site Cu catalysts on ceria with more ionic Cu-O bonds (Cu1 O(I)/CeO2) and with more covalent Cu-O bonds (Cu1 O(C)/CeO2) could be obtained by synthetic procedure control. Interestingly, the more ionic Cu-O bond makes Cu1 O(I)/CeO2 display a much higher activity than Cu1 O(C)/CeO2 in selective hydroboration of alkynes. Based on this work, they then designed and synthesized a Cu1Ti4 C single-atomic-site catalyst for studying reaction mechanisms through strong electronic metal-support interaction (EMSI) effects (Scheme 13 ) [42]. Notably, the authors have demonstrated the advantages and potential of EMSI in regioselective regulation. By combining the chemistry of MOFs, Li and coworkers have developed a new interfacial synthesis method to prepare 2D copper(I) cyclic trinuclear unit (Cu-CTU)-based MOFs (2D-JNM-4) from copper salt, 3,5-dimethyl-1H-pyrazol-4-amine and pyromellitic dianhydride. Then 2D-JNM-4 can be exfoliated into free-standing 2D MONs, denoted to JNM-4-Ns. Interestingly, JNM-4-Ns exhibit high catalytic activity and superior reusability for the hydroboration of alkynes in water solution at room temperature (Scheme 14 ) [43]. The great diversity and modularity of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) provide favorable opportunities to design new catalysts with multimetal chemical states. Li and Liu reported a Cu-MOF consisting of paddlewheel CuII dimers linked together by trimesic acid anions (BTC) and containing Keggin H3PW12O40 (HMP) guests, named NENU-3 ([Cu12(BTC)8(H2O)12][H3PW12O40]), which could mediate hydroboration of diverse alkynes (Scheme 15 ) [44]. Due to the CuII-CuI HMP sites featuring a unique coordination configuration, it showed excellent catalytic performance for hydroboration of alkyne with additive-free under mild conditions. Zhao and coworkers constructed a stable [CuxIy] cluster-based MOF, {[CuIICuI 4I4(-PMCA)2(Py)]NH(CH3)2 .3DMF} (PMCA= pyrimidine-5-carboxylic acid, Py = pyridine), which could efficiently catalyze the hydroboration of various alkynes with bis(pinacolato)diboron (B2Pin2) at room temperature (Scheme 16 ) [45]. Zhang et al. described the anti-Markovnikov hydroboration of alkynes with bis(pinacoloto)diboron (B2pin2) as boron reagent and zirconium-based porphyrinic MOFs as catalyst (formulated as (Zr6(μ 3 OH)8(OH)8-(TCPP)2, named as PCN-222 (Cu)) (Scheme 17 ) [46]. The control experiments and DFT calculations were conducted to investigate the mechanism. Then they concluded that the synergistic effect of Cu(II) ions, N atoms of porphyrin rings and terminal -OH groups on Zr-nodes were playing an important role for improving catalytic activity of PCN-222(Cu). The inclusion of copper within the nanocluster family offers cost-reduction advantages and opens new opportunities for applications in sustainable synthesis and catalysis due to its easily accessible oxidation states and flexible ligand architectures. In 2024, Bakr et al. reported the synthesis of an atomically precise copper nanocluster with a planar core and unique shell, [Cu45(TBBT)29(TPP)4(C4H11N)2H14]2+ (Cu45) (TBBT: 4‑tert-butylbenzenethiol; TPP: triphenylphosphine), in high yield via a one-pot reduction method. It could be used as efficient catalyst for hydroboration of alkynes via the formation of boryl-centered radicals (Scheme 18 ) [47]. Notably, the nanocluster interacted with borate ate complex to give the boryl radical via a single electron transfer(SET). Subsequently, a dual-catalytic site copper clusters, [Cu4(NHT)4] (Cu4) (NHT=1-methyl-1H-imidazole-2(3H)-thione), was synthesized in the gram scale by Zang and coworkers (Scheme 19 ) [48]. It also exhibited excellent regio-, stereo- and chemoselectivity in hydroboration of alkynes with high TON (up to 77,786), which is the highest reported catalytic efficiency so far (Table 1 ). As shown in Scheme 19, the key points of the catalytic cycle was dynamic dissociation of two flexible Cu-N bonds between the Cu4 metal core and the NHT ligands, releasing the catalytic center to enhance the catalytic activity and promote the generation of the key intermediate Cu4 OH (I) in a deuterated alkaline protic solution. In view of the significance of the structure activity relationship between the cluster catalysts and their catalytic properties, this work offers a model for designing heterogeneous cluster catalysts for catalytic research. 2.2 Nano iron catalyzed hydroboration of alkynes In 2014, Sreedhar and coworkers reported magnetic Fe3O4 nanoparticles catalyzed the hydroboration of alkynes using bis(pinacolato)diboron to provide E-vinyl boronates with high regio- and stereoselectivity in good to excellent yields (Scheme 20 ) [49]. One of the added advantages of this catalyst is that it can be readily separated from the reaction mixture by simply applying an external magnetic field and then reused in the next run. Subsequently, Garcia et al. reported MgO-supported iron NPs as catalyst in the monoborylation of alkynes with bis(pinacolato)diboron reagent by the PPh3-assisted (Scheme 21 ) [50]. Interestingly, the authors also explored the catalytic activity of the Pt supported on MgO or active carbon. The results showed that it could promote the stereoselective hydroboration of alkynes at lower temperature in the absence of triphenylphosphine. Notably, the reaction mechanism was same to Scheme 1. In 2023, Zhang and coworkers described a bench-stable 3-D Fe-MOF assembled from the direct reaction of ditopic 4′-pyridyl-2,2′:6′,2′′-terpyridine with FeCl2, this catalyst was found to be highly effective in the syn-selective hydroboration of alkynes with HBpin under solvent-free conditions (Scheme 22 ) [51]. The nanoscale grid in the framework adopts a dimension of 2.2 × 2.2 nm. More interestingly, the potential catalytic application was demonstrated in a recyclability of the Fe-MOF catalyst. 2.3 Cerium catalyzed hydroboration of alkynes Based on rare-earth catalyst Sm had been used for the hydroboration of CC triple bond in homogeneous systems and Ce-BTC (BTC=trimesic acid) MOF could catalyze hydroboration of alkenes with HBPin as boron reagent [52]. Bose and coworkers reported a heterogeneous CeO2 nanorods catalyst for the hydroboration of alkynes with B2Pin2 as boron reagent (Scheme 23 ) [53]. Notably, the CeO2 nanorods catalyst was synthesized by a template-free hydrothermal method. The TEM images show nanorods structure has a diameter of 2.5 nm. Reaction mechanism was similarly to Scheme 3. In addition, CeO2 nanorods also proved to be efficient catalyst for the hydroboration of acetophenone and alkenes. 2.4 Bimetallic rhodium–ruthenium NPs catalyzed hydroboration of alkynes The immobilization of metal nanoparticles on multi-walled carbon nanotubes (CNT) can provide a significantly enhanced catalytic activity in various organic transformations. In 2023, Nunes and coworkers have reported their findings on bimetallic rhodium-ruthenium nanoparticles on CNT for the hydroboration of alkyl alkynes (Scheme 24 ) [54]. The features of this system was low catalyst loadings (0.04 mol%), solvent-free, and recyclability of catalyst. Moreover, it could also used to the hydroboration of alkyl alkenes with high turnover number (TON=2400). The mechanistic investigation suggested that rhodium and ruthenium acted synergistically, and oxidative addition of the B-H bond to the metal center play important role for the key step insertion of the alkene into the rhodium-hydride to form an active intermediate. 2.5 Bimetallic Gold–Copper nanoclusters catalyzed hydroboration of alkynes Interestingly, atomically precise metal nanoclusters have attracted much attention in catalysis because of tunable compositions and structures. In 2023, Wu and Li reported that the ligand-modified [Au1Cu14(4- t BuPhS)12(PPh3)6]SbF6 (Au1Cu14) shown an excellent catalytic property in the hyd- roboration of alkynes under ambient light conditions at room temperatur (Scheme 25 ) [55]. Various terminal and internal alkynes worked well with B2Pin2 to produce the desired products in good yields with high stereoselectivity. Notably, the TOFs were achieved up to 4850 h-1 with 0.01 mol% catalyst loading and the Au1Cu14 nanocluster could be recycled at least six times. The control experiments demonstrated that a single electron transfer between Au1Cu14 and B2Pin2 occured in the presence of K2CO3 to generated Bpin• was playing a key role in the catalytic cycle. 2.6 Platinum NPs catalyzed hydroboration of alkynes In the past decades, elegant examples of hydroboration of alkynes have been disclosed using supported copper, gold, iron, and rhenium nanoparticles as heterogeneous metal catalysts. In fact, the catalytic activity of heterogeneous platinum-based catalyst in general hydroboration of alkynes had also been realized [56]. For example, Leeuwen and coworkers have reported the hydroboration of alkynes to vinylboronates using a soluble platinum nanoparticles ligated by long-chain N-heterocyclic carbenes as catalyst [57]. In 2020, Conejero and coworkers reported an N-heterocyclic thiones (NHT) stabilized platinum nanoparticles (1.3–1.7 nm) for hydroboration of various alkynes with 4,4,5,5-tetramethyl-1,3,2-dioxaborolane (Scheme 26 ) [58]. Additionally, when using aliphatic alkynes as starting materials, the vinylboronate products could be further hydroborated to the 1,1- and 1,2-diborylated alkanes. 3 Conclusion and perspectives In summary, metal nanoparticles or nanoclusters catalysis has been of great interest in hydroboration of alkynes and has expanded rapidly in the past fifteen years due to the nano metal catalysts’ unique reactivity and selectivity, as well as recyclability in catalytic reactions. Specially, from the point view of atom-economic and environmental benign, metal-based nanocatalysis used in organic synthesis has increased spectacularly in recent years. It has been proven to be an effective strategy to develop metal nanocatalysts for hydroboration reactions with excellent efficiency and selectivity. Although we did not detailed discuss the synthetic procedures of nanocatalysts and the catalytic activity of metal sites in this review, the effect of inorganic or polymeric materials support for meal nanocatalysis is fascinating since it has enabled unprecedented highly reactive and stereoselective catalysis for hydroboration of alkynes. Indeed, despite much progress in this field, further advancements and challenges still remain. For example, significant challenges involves in synthesis of metal nanocatalysts for balancing catalytic activity with stability. The exploration of the synthetic strategies for developing advanced supports that enhance stability without significantly blocking active sites [59]. In addition, a burgeoning trend in nanocatalysis involves the exploration of single-atom catalysis (SAC), which represents a paradigm shift in catalyst design toward the increase of sustainability and efficiency [60]. Moreover, rational design metal nanocatalysts with artificial intelligence (AI) technology may help fully researchers to predict and optimize catalytic properties with a level of control [61]. For examples, Jiang and co-workers use spectroscopic descriptors with machine learning to establish a quantitative spectral structure–property relationship for adsorbed molecules on metal monatomic catalysts [62]. Advances in density functional theory (DFT) have enabled researchers to predict catalyst properties before synthesis [63]. Furthermore, compared to homogeneous metal catalysis, heterogeneous catalysts for Markovnikov-type hydroboration of terminal alkynes is still challenging and less explored [64]. coredata.dc:description: The hydroboration of alkynes using transition metal catalysts is one of the most straightforward and effective methods for synthesizing value-added vinylboronates that support various industries, including materials science, agrochemicals and pharmaceuticals. However, most existing reports focus on homogeneous catalysis and are largely limited to recover the catalysts and metal contamination into products. In recent years, the use of metal-based heterogeneous catalysts has emerged as a powerful strategy to overcome these limitations. In this mini review, we summarize the employment of nanometal catalysts in the hydroboration reactions, and the related mechanisms are also discussed. Additionally, we discuss the challenges and future perspectives for promoting nanocatalysis, highlighting the potential to drive advancements towards sustainability in hydroboration of alkynes.
